Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A contested motion is scheduled soon, and the client relies on effective advocacy to preserve their position.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: Sunday morning sunlight filtered through my office window as I reviewed the case file for tomorrow’s hearing. My client’s future hinged on my preparation; the contested motion was critical, and I knew I needed every spare moment to be ready. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: church service in an hour. As a Christian, I was expected to be present, to worship, and to join the community in prayer and fellowship. My pastor had even asked me to help with the youth group after the service. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my client’s anxious voice from our last call echoed in my mind, while the memory of last week’s sermon about faithfulness tugged at my conscience. I stared at my open laptop, legal notes blurring with the words of hymns I should soon be singing. My heart pounded as I wrestled with the impossible choice: to serve my client with undivided attention, or to honor my commitment to my faith and community.
